Award.AbstractNarration: This travel award will support student participation in the IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) to be held from March 21st to March 25th, 2011, in Seattle, Washington. This is the flagship conference of the pervasive computing community. The conference offers a valuable opportunity to present research results, to learn about the state of the art in pervasive computing, and to train doctoral students through the PhD forum. Of particular value to participating students will be the PhD Forum. In addition to a traditional PhD Forum that consists primarily of poster presentations, the 2011 conference will extend the forum to include a more concrete benefit to student participants. In particular, the PerCom 2011 PhD Forum will include a closed session for participants that will take place one day before the conference starts. The students and the Forum committee members (approximately 6 individuals) will come together for a working session to discuss concerns related to performing PhD research and building a post-dissertation career. Specifically, topics discussed in the Forum will include discussions on how to formulate and follow through on research questions, discussions and critiques of presenting research ideas and solutions, discussions and demonstrations on providing evidence to support research, and a panel focused on how to launch and sustain a research career. The travel awards will focus on particularly recruiting women and minority students to attend the conference by advertising the support opportunity on the PerCom web page and on web sites targeted toward women and minority students, including NSF-sponsored IGERT and REU web sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) is a high
quality conference sponsored by IEEE Computer Society's Technical Committee on Computer
Communications (TCCC) and Technical Committee on Distributed Computing (TCDP).Since the
beginning of the conference in 2003, it has established itself as a premier annual event for researchers in
pervasive computing and communications, as well as related areas. The conference has become extremely
competitive, with paper acceptance rates consistently lying below 20%. Papers presented at the
conference are of very high quality. The number of submissions has been rising steadily which shows the
interests and level of research activity in the community. In recent years, PerCom was held in Hong
Kong, Texas, and Mannheim, Germany.

The 2011 conference was held in Seattle, Washington. The conference had about 250 attendees. The
program included 13 workshops, a main technical program, a demonstrations session, a poster session, a
PhD Forum, two keynote talks, and a panel discussion. Conference details are found online at
http://www.percom.org. The proceedings of the meeting are published as an IEEE publication, fully
searchable and downloadable via IEEE Xplore. IEEE PerCom is a high quality conference and the
premier IEEE technical forum dedicated to addressing the key challenges and identifying future directions
in pervasive computing and aware networking including wireless, mobile, mesh and sensor networks,
middleware, ambient intelligence, pervasive services and applications. Selected (extended) papers from
the 2011 conference will also be invited for publication in a special issue of the Elsevier's Pervasive and
Mobile Computing (PMC) journal.


To help increase the representation and participation of United States-based graduate students in this
conference, this NSF award was used to help cover the travel expenses for 18 students. The travel award
program specifically targeted graduate students because they are an important segment of the research
community.

To select travel grant award recipients, a Call For Proposals was posted on the PerCom site and
publicized widely throughout the community. Each proposal included information about the student, a
statement indicating how the student would benefit from attending the conference, and a letter from the
student’s advisor describing the status of the student. A committee of three faculty, consisting of Diane
Cook, Jie Liu, and Christine Julien, reviewed each of the proposals and selected 18 award recipients.
Each of the recipients accepted the invitation. In addition to attending the conference and workshops, the
recipients spent some time helping with the administration of the conference. This award allowed them to
attend the conference, learn from the talks, and through their work interact with leading researchers in the
field.
